So I put this huge thing up just
to get people thinking ahead of time. I want to give you all first
a sense of the applied problem

about human interaction. One example is where we
do these experiments. I do have to say before
I start, the disclaimer

is I'm from Trinidad and
Tobago in the Caribbean. People tell me that-- I have to say this
because otherwise they

miss the first part of my talk,
trying to guess where I'm from. Now you all know. I have your full attention.

If you want to read
more about these papers, there's our website papers. And I have the link
to my research,

tiny.ccwilliamsresarch, which
is basically an overview of what I put in for tenure. And this URl,
tiny.cc/jointaiextended,

is our mailing list. So you can join
that and then you can listen in whenever
we have a lab meeting. For a special meeting,
we announce it,

and you can always
pop by and listen in. We're trying to think of
a global network of people involved in adapting
experiments.

So here are my
objectives for this talk. By the end this
talk, I want everyone to be able to have some
kind of shareable message.

You could tell someone else what
is interesting in a paragraph, in a person-- you could tell the
person next to you.

By email, you could send
them a link to this talk and tell them why
it's interesting, or maybe a LinkedIn
or Twitter post.

You want to have some kind
of concrete information that comes out of this
and being able to explain how adaptive
experimentation can be

used in a wide range of
behavior change contexts. Well, you have ideas for
how you could contribute

to helping someone
win a Nobel Prize for adaptive experimentation. I also want you all to have
a clear to-do or could-do.

What's one thing you could do? Before you saw this talk,
you're on one trajectory. After, what are you
going to do differently?

Is it going to have any impact? Would it be joining
mailing list, reading a particular paper, or
share these slides with someone,

or give feedback? The world should
change in some way after we spent an hour
together and more.

So think about your hashtag
shareable message on [INAUDIBLE] could do. You'll be quizzed at the end.

All right. So this is the overview of
the talk I gave yesterday. Fundamentally, what's
the goal of our program?

It's to coach behavior change. For example, how
do we coach people to learn more effectively? Like I just did,
by prompting you

to have a clear, shareable
message, or a to-do. How do we coach people
to manage stress better?

How do we coach people to
exercise, to eat healthier? And what's our approach to that? Our approach is that we
transform everyday technology

touchpoints into
intelligent interventions. And I'll say what
that means and how the adoption framework
supports that and helps

us win the Xprize. So there are three
components to this work. The first is adaptive
experimentation tools

to make experimentation
easier and expedited because this gives us more
effective interventions.

For example, it gives us better
explanations of a concept. It gives us messages that
will help someone actually

deal with stress better. The second theme is
personalized and contextualized interventions.

And the papers I
present there are all work by Ananya Bhattacharjee
and others in my lab. And finally, adaptive
experimentation

to accelerate
science and practice. Now, that's what the actual
full talk will be on. I'm going to abbreviate the
first two parts just to give you

a taste of an example or two. So you can keep that in mind. Now, the science
of behavior change can help solve many
human problems.

Imagine if you could get
the magic words to change any behavior. What behaviors you wish
you could start doing?

Is it introducing yourself
to people, exercising,

connecting better,
being less stressed? What behaviours do you
wish you'd stop doing? Is it that you just don't speak
up when you know you should?

Is it that you keep eating
10 snacks instead of two? Are you scrolling on Instagram
or other things way too much?

Nathan [? Laundry, ?] one of
my students, works on that. Also behavior change in others. What behaviors do you wish
others would do more or less

often, in different contexts? And you all see how this touches
on every aspect of what we do.

Change your behavior
in learning, making better decisions, exercise
eating, stress, happiness.

And I'll focus--
in the examples, I'll look at how
technology can help us

in behavior change in
both education and health.

So the vision we're
looking for is by 2034, how do we have on-demand
intelligent coaches

that measurably help people
think through many problems and change their
behavior for good?

What have we done so far
to get to that point? From 2012 to 2024, we've
given a foundation.

And this is through
the AdapComp framework which helps us get
tools for designing intelligent interventions.

An intelligent
intervention, whether it's a text message you get sent or
an app message or an explanation

of a concept, is an intervention
that changes your behavior. And it's intelligently
sensitive that it tries to come up with what's
the best thing to give you

at this point in time? But also, true intelligence
is about learning. It's constantly
testing out ideas

so you can learn what
is going to help you. If someone tells you they
built an intelligence system and it doesn't involve learning
and continuous learning--

I have lots of snake oil
I'd like to sell you. And to built intelligent
interventions,

we have to integrate
multiple disciplines. So what are examples of
intelligent interventions we've been working on that
can help towards this coaching

behavior change? So what we do is
we essentially take

components of
everyday experience and make them into AdapComps. The AdapComp framework takes
a static user interface

like a text message or a
website and makes a micro lab for intelligent intervention.

We keep testing out ideas
and improving them over time. For example, text
messages is one

that Ananya Bhattacharjee and
others have been involved in. Imagine you get a message of
the day, but that's an AdapComp.

And what that means is
we crowdsource many ideas for those. So we keep testing
them out, use LLMs,

use people's input to
generate ideas and messages, and then we try and
figure out which of those is best for you when.

When do we emphasize get
up and go for a walk? Now you've got to do it. When you tell someone it's
OK to feel kind of lazy,

you can take a
break for 10 minutes and come back to this later. The idea is we
want to figure out as a coach, what are we going to
say to the right moment in time.

Think of emails as well. One of your students who just
got a job as a faculty member

has focused on emails
you sent people to get them to start
homework early. But again, we've tried
dozens of options

for all sorts of human beings
and adapt through LLMs. I'm trying to figure out when do
they work in different contexts.

But do you see we take
something as boring as email and turn that into
intelligent coach? The AdapComp lets you take the
subject line, the intro message

and generate multiple versions
and test out what works well. So anything you
touch every day could be an intelligent intervention.

Of course, you can imagine
explanations on websites. Sadly, I will be embarrassed
to say my website is not

intelligent intervention. You get the same thing that's
been there for six months, and you should shame me for
it until I fix that problem.

When you show up on my website,
you should have an AdapComp. It should randomize you
to different explanations.

It should let you say,
Joseph, this was garbage. Here's a better
explanation, and it should be A/B testing that to
figure out which explanations

are better on average
and what works for you at this moment in time. Does that make
sense, how you want

to make that piece of
a website in AdapComp? We have actually done a better
job in other people's websites.

In 2013, when I was at
Berkeley and Stanford, we actually ran experiments
with Khan Academy, where we would actually test
out different explanations

of concepts, different
messages to motivate students to work harder. And increasingly, now
we're doing it in LLMs.

I want to say for all
the good LLMs are doing, aren't you all a bit frustrated? In an LLM, it's so easy to
generate alternative versions.

Anything in conversation, they
can make dozens of versions of. And they don't do it. Why they're not A/B
testing LLM components?

When you go to ChatGPT and
it gives you an answer, it could test 10
versions of that answer to figure out what's going
to actually help you.

They have introduced
some nice features, but those are just first steps. They can be A/B testing
200 times more than that.

So does this give
you all a sense of how everything you
touch in the world could be in other AdapComp. It could be an
intelligent intervention

that tests out different
versions and changes over time. Who's sold on us?

Who understands what I'm saying? You have to be [? still, ?]
once you understand. So I wrote this in
the chat, but I'm

unclear about how
you're going to have sufficient statistical
power for these. These are small exchanges.

The impact on let's
say click through rate is going to be very small. So you're going to need to send
the email to tens of thousands

of people. Yes. How does that work? I understand if you're a portal
and you've got all the users,

but for everybody
else out there, you're saying send an email.

This is not a major
spam to 100,000 users. You're not going to
have statistical power.

That's a great point. So I appreciate the question. So if we want to make this
approach too ubiquitous,

how can we make this possible? Because you won't have
enough data to do this. So I'll say two things.

One is that we take this
approach in settings like education
and mental health,

where we've actually
built collaborations to do this at scale. So if you do have 500,
1,000, even 200 people,

you can apply this approach. But the second thing
I would say this-- this is exactly what
we're doing next.

So one of our papers, you
can read on our website, it's called A/
ABScribe by Mohi Reza. That's about
qualitative A/B testing.

What if you actually could take
the best features of A/B testing and use them qualitatively?

Even if I'm only to send
an email to one person, how can I actually
gather feedback to understand the
different options?

It's also connected
to something I would call a thought
A/B experiment. Tell me something, when
you're writing an email,

could it actually make
sense to use an ABScribe tool to make different
versions and then try and think
through in your head

how these would come together? So you get no data. It's all in your head, but
the process of A/B testing

will make you lay
out alternatives and think about the impact. And that's actually what I
want to do a lot more work in.

Yes. I guess conceptually,
A/B testing is this statistical rather
than qualitative method,

at least the formal definition. I wonder if there's a name clash
thing where maybe that's not

the right name for it. That is exactly my point. The word A/B testing means
something to everyone.

I'm trying to come and tell
you all this thing here that you call a chair, it's now
going to be something we fly on.

OK? So that's a great point. So here's the exercise. Everyone, here's how you
can contribute about-- here's how you can contribute
to a crowdsource Nobel, OK?

Come up with a different
word for those A/B tests that are actually a qualitative.

Qualitative A/B comparisons,
super A/B comparisons. That's your exercise
for homework, OK?

And then I can take it
and you can charge me if I have made money off of it.

For now, I'm going to call them
a qualitative A/B comparison. All right. So now in terms of intelligent
interventions, here's a process.

And I want to get
you all thinking, how could this process
work even if you do not

have quantitative data? So here the elements. You take an AdapComp, like one
of those messages we just saw

and you now think part
one, how do I make it easy to generate options?

For example, if I'm
writing an email, how to generate alternative
versions using both LLMs and crowdsourcing human beings.

And then explore that
space of options, come up with better and better ideas.

Part two, now, how do I expedite
the evaluation of these options? What might be more or
less promising, but also,

how do I expedite execution? What do I mean by execution? I mean actually using
adaptive experiments

to give people
what looks better, to integrate reinforce
learning and human judgment.

So a very concrete
example would be, let's say we have two
versions of an email.

I can ask you, what's
the probability of email A is better than email B? If you tell me--

actually, can I
ask you in the red? What's the probability that's-- let me show you an actual email. OK.

I'll just make it up. There are two emails
hidden in my hands. What's the probability
A is better than B?

Like where do the
emails come from? You know nothing else. 50%. 50/50, right? Well, look at that.

You think there's a 50% chance. So why don't we assign
with 50% probability? What do we have?

Classic A/B testing. Now, she unfortunately
knows more than you, and she says there's a 70%
chance A is better than B.
So what should we do? Assign that to 70% of people. Does that make sense?

Well, I'll pick on
because I know him. He's like, no, if
there's a 70% chance, you should give everyone
at 100% in time.

That's actually what we all do. We are arrogant, right? When I write an email, I send
the email, 100% of the time,

I'm saying I'm 100%
sure that is the best email I could have sent you. I did no randomization.

So you see? We live in a terrible world. Like Daniel Kahneman said,
where binary creatures living

in a probabilistic world. We either give someone
something 100% of the time. I'm giving you one version of
this presentation 100% in time.

Or we give you some 50/50. We don't have these in-betweens. An adaptive A/B experiment
says let's randomize

with weighted randomization
proportional to our belief. So if you think, like she does,
there's a 70% chance A is better

that B, why don't you
give it a 70% of people and give it to 30% of people?

Then you get more data. And this data can
be quantitative or it can be
qualitative as well.

You might just see people react
negatively and say 70/30 is too high. I think it's
actually like 20/80.

So the idea here is let's start
rethinking the world to not just give a 100 versus 0,
just one best thing,

and not just give 50/50,
which is A/B testing, only we have no idea. Let's actually give
things proportional

to the probability
we think that there's going to have the best outcome. Does that make sense, everyone?

At least conceptually,
do you all get the idea that
we could actually start assigning items or
actions, emails, texts,

things we see? Proportionally,
probability, we think that they're the best where
best has to be defined.

How do you decide the
complexity of the model that you're using to weigh
your different versions

against-- like, for example,
with the Khan Academy example, which LLM response
is the best one to elicit

a particular action? I presume you have to build
some kind of probabilistic model in the background for your
estimate of the beliefs

of the student, but
there are many ways of doing that and many different
ways to plan subsequent actions.

And I guess, is that something
that happens real time or is that something
that happens once before

and then you implement a
system that just runs or? And what's the process
of even figuring out

what are the relevant
components of your model? Excellent questions. And I have the answer.

You can always answer in
anything that's worth answering. Two words, it depends.

Those are fantastic questions. Those are the questions we're
going to spend the next 25 years working on. What is the model you're using
to set those probabilities?

I will give you one
model today for two arm case, A and B, binary
outcomes, and I

will show you that model
actually isn't even good enough. But you know what, for some
[? next ?] you might say,

I want to do
qualitative A/B testing and they say I'm going to set
those probabilities by a crowd sourced mixture of experts.

I'm going to get the best
marketing people in the world and we're going to ask them
questions about 10 emails. They're going to all
give us weightings,

I'm going to combine them. Then we send it out. I'm going to send them
the data of what happens and get the market people
to update their beliefs.

That's an alternative method. I don't know of any papers
that have done that. I'm sure five have, but
five is basically none.

We need a lot more work
on getting human beings to set those probabilities. But I will give you
examples of how we've done

that using statistical models. Again, I want to say that's
good, that's fine, right? But I think we can do a lot more
innovative, interesting work.

And most importantly,
like I said, how do we give these
techniques to 8 billion people?

8 billion people are not
going to run A/b test. I love them. I'll run them. You will too. 8 billion people will send
emails and text messages.

They may, with the right
tools that we built, randomize them a bit.

Yeah. So I want to make sure I'm
understanding your intention so far.

What's my intention so far. We think about statistics
in A/B testing formally,

but in reality, we
just write one email. Yes. And so you're suggesting
that we should explore

this in-between space
where we don't necessarily have formal statistical
power, but we have

all these other signals
about how did the person reply to this email,
or how did you

feel when you sent A versus B? Like, all these other proxies
that might qualitatively

give you the answer about what
you think is the best to send, but in reality, we're just
like sending one email.

And so you're trying to push
us to think this kind of-- I have never said
it so well myself.

Good thing we're recording. What's your intention
today, Joseph? It is to get us to rethink the
way we're making decisions,

to bring some elements of A/B
testing together to help us think about the signals we
get, about what might be better

or worse, and help us to start
to actually randomize with weighted randomization or
something where we don't just

have 50/50 or /100, we
have something in between. And I think anything that moves
us towards that is progress.

Anything that makes
me realize that when I send an email to someone,
it's worth having two versions, even if I don't send it, I
build the habit of A/B testing,

of qualitative A/B
testing is progress. Why? Because we're introducing a
problem to solve a problem.

Just like the person-- that's why I'm calling
you all by what you're wearing-- in the
white Stanford hoodie said, just as they said, how do you
choose those probabilities?

Good. Now you have a problem to solve. The fact that you're
worrying about that is going to give me
a lot of confidence.

I will say what we have done,
which I think is really good and can be a lot better and
is a big research program

is work on those models

and Sang Truong is

qualitative work will help
the crowdsource approaches. And here's one way of seeing it.

how many fields

medalists have helped people
